entries.text: One of the virtues of Perl is the long backward compatibility, but the developers of Mojolicious play by a different ruleset. They are ready to break backward compatibility to allow for development. It certainly has the disadvantage when it bites you, but maybe that's a better choice than being stuck with features that could be provided in a better way, or that were just plain wrong even when they were introudced. Perl has plenty of both. By being ready to pay the price of incompatible changes Mojolicious can clean up these issues.

entries.text: This post has two main points IMHO unfortunately mixed. One is that by focusing too much on being a 'Perl programmer' many of us have and still miss out on a lot of great things knowing other languages can offer. Not just employment opportunities, but by knowing other languages you can become better at Perl as well. The other point felt by some people as an attack on the 'Perl programmers Facebook group' which, I think was unfortunate. In any case I wholeheartadly recommend you read it and diversify your knowledge.

header: A long time ago I participated in many discussion about the Perl community and how to bring in more people to it, but nowadays I am not surewhat that title would cover. Others are discussing it.

As for me, I try to help people whether it is with knowledge about Perl, other programming language, or other technologies. I hope sometimes my work is useful to others as well. Which bring me to the recent seesion I had with FErki in which he helped me and the other participants get started with automation using Rex. Next week we are going to have another session to which you are invited.
